articles.headline: Trump Vows to Unveil Tax-Cut Plan Next Week, Surprising Staff
articles.snippet: Eager to roll back Dodd-Frank legislation and overhaul the tax code, President Trump directed the Treasury Department to review measures that would curtail corporate tax evasion.
articles.abstract: Eager to roll back Dodd-Frank legislation and overhaul the tax code, President Trump directed the Treasury Department to review measures that would curtail corporate tax evasion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump promised on Friday that he would unveil a “massive” tax cut for Americans next week, vowing a “big announcement on Wednesday,” but he revealed no details about what is certain to be an enormously complicated effort to overhaul the nation’s tax code.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren on Big Banks and Their (Cozy Bedmate) Regulators
articles.snippet: In a new book, the Democratic senator from Massachusetts takes Wells Fargo to task, along with the system that let it get away with account fraud.
articles.abstract: In a new book, the Democratic senator from Massachusetts takes Wells Fargo to task, along with the system that let it get away with account fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo’s board and management are scheduled to meet shareholders at the company’s annual meeting Tuesday in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. With the phony account-opening scandal still making headlines, and the company’s stock underperforming its peers, it’s a good bet the bank’s brass will have some explaining to do.

articles.headline: Russian Hacker Sentenced to 27 Years in Credit Card Case
articles.snippet: The schemes of Roman Seleznev led to the theft and resale of more than two million credit card numbers, resulting in losses of at least $170 million.
articles.abstract: The schemes of Roman Seleznev led to the theft and resale of more than two million credit card numbers, resulting in losses of at least $170 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have yet to capture or convict the foreign computer criminals believed to be behind the hackings of big retailers like Target and Neiman Marcus.

articles.headline: Oscar Munoz Won’t Get Planned Promotion to Chairman of United
articles.snippet: The company also said it would revise executive compensation based on the airline’s customer performance after a high-profile misstep.
articles.abstract: The company also said it would revise executive compensation based on the airline’s customer performance after a high-profile misstep.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of United Airlines, Oscar Munoz, became a casualty of the public relations crisis gripping the air carrier, as the company that runs the airline said on Friday that he would not ascend as planned to the role of chairman.

articles.headline: How Child Care Enriches Mothers, and Generations to Come
articles.snippet: Government spending on high-quality day care in a child’s early years delivers an economic boon that lasts three generations, research finds.
articles.abstract: Government spending on high-quality day care in a child’s early years delivers an economic boon that lasts three generations, research finds.
articles.lead_paragraph: As many American parents know, hiring care for young children during the workday is punishingly expensive, costing the typical family about a third of its income.

articles.headline: At a ‘Unity’ Stop in Nebraska, Democrats Find Anything But
articles.snippet: At the center of the debate over the party’s future is Senator Bernie Sanders, who has emerged as the most popular active politician in America, but he isn’t even a Democrat.
articles.abstract: At the center of the debate over the party’s future is Senator Bernie Sanders, who has emerged as the most popular active politician in America, but he isn’t even a Democrat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rarely has a municipal election in a midsize city ignited such a fierce national debate over what defines a Democrat. But the election this spring for mayor of Omaha is pitting abortion rights activists against economic populists and threatening the party’s unity as it regroups to confront President Trump.

articles.headline: How Airline Workers Learn to Deal With You
articles.snippet: A class in “verbal judo” offers a window on how flight crews are taught to defuse situations with naughty, uncooperative or tipsy passengers.
articles.abstract: A class in “verbal judo” offers a window on how flight crews are taught to defuse situations with naughty, uncooperative or tipsy passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVANSVILLE, Wyo. — The father who fell under suspicion for human trafficking while traveling with his daughter. The couple accused by United of self-upgrading who were downgraded right off their flight. An American Airlines employee who confronted a mother with a stroller. And Dr. David Dao, dragged and bloodied, who earned a place in aviation history that he probably did not want.

articles.headline: ‘A Shortage of Coffins’ After Taliban Slaughter Unarmed Soldiers
articles.snippet: Details were still emerging, but it appeared to have been the single deadliest known attack on an Afghan military base since the war began.
articles.abstract: Details were still emerging, but it appeared to have been the single deadliest known attack on an Afghan military base since the war began.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — They looked like Afghan Army soldiers returning from the front lines, carrying the bodies of wounded comrades as part of the ruse.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Najim Rahim

articles.headline: Comey Tried to Shield the F.B.I. From Politics. Then He Shaped an Election.
articles.snippet: As the F.B.I. investigated Hillary Clinton and the Trump campaign, James B. Comey tried to keep the bureau out of politics but plunged it into the center of a bitter election.
articles.abstract: As the F.B.I. investigated Hillary Clinton and the Trump campaign, James B. Comey tried to keep the bureau out of politics but plunged it into the center of a bitter election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day before he upended the 2016 election, James B. Comey, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, summoned agents and lawyers to his conference room. They had been debating all day, and it was time for a decision.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Michael S. Schmidt, Adam Goldman and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: In House of Murdoch, Sons Set About an Elaborate Overhaul
articles.snippet: Since taking over two years ago, James and Lachlan Murdoch seem determined to rid the company of the old-guard culture on which their father built his empire.
articles.abstract: Since taking over two years ago, James and Lachlan Murdoch seem determined to rid the company of the old-guard culture on which their father built his empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sun was setting in New York as James Murdoch, looking confident in cream pants and a dark blazer, stepped before 350 guests in a glass-walled concert hall and waxed poetic about his pet TV channel and its dedication to “scientific literacy.”
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Trump Reaches Beyond West Wing for Counsel
articles.snippet: The president has turned to a group of advisers — from family, real estate, media, finance and politics — all of whom are outside the White House gates
articles.abstract: The president has turned to a group of advisers — from family, real estate, media, finance and politics — all of whom are outside the White House gates
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Relationships have always been President Trump’s currency and comfort, helping him talk his way into real estate deals over three decades in New York. Those who know him best say that his outer confidence has always belied an inner uncertainty, and that he needs to test ideas with a wide range of people.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: As the French Go to the Polls, Uncertainty Is the Only Sure Bet
articles.snippet: The presidential election on Sunday is one of the most consequential in recent times — not just for France, but for Europe — and one of the most unpredictable, too.
articles.abstract: The presidential election on Sunday is one of the most consequential in recent times — not just for France, but for Europe — and one of the most unpredictable, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For at least the last three French elections, voters in the town of Louviers, about 60 miles northwest of Paris, have cast ballots for the candidate who ultimately won the presidency. So who are they voting for on Sunday, in the country’s closest race in memory?

articles.headline: Trump's Industry, Real Estate, Poses Hurdle to Tax Overhaul
articles.snippet: The president, who says a sweeping plan is coming, has embraced positions that would benefit developers — a powerful lobby — and complicate changes.
articles.abstract: The president, who says a sweeping plan is coming, has embraced positions that would benefit developers — a powerful lobby — and complicate changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump has promised a sweeping tax plan, arriving in the days ahead, that will be “bigger, I believe, than any tax cut ever.” It will aim to bring down individual and corporate rates, simplify the overall tax code and unleash economic growth.

articles.headline: Uber’s C.E.O. Plays With Fire
articles.snippet: Travis Kalanick’s drive to win in life has led to a pattern of risk-taking that has at times put his ride-hailing company on the brink of implosion.
articles.abstract: Travis Kalanick’s drive to win in life has led to a pattern of risk-taking that has at times put his ride-hailing company on the brink of implosion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Travis Kalanick, the chief executive of Uber, visited Apple’s headquarters in early 2015 to meet with Timothy D. Cook, who runs the iPhone maker. It was a session that Mr. Kalanick was dreading.

articles.headline: Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen Advance in French Election
articles.snippet: Mr. Macron, a political novice, and Ms. Le Pen, a far-right firebrand, will advance to a runoff vote next month after voters rejected the mainstream parties.
articles.abstract: Mr. Macron, a political novice, and Ms. Le Pen, a far-right firebrand, will advance to a runoff vote next month after voters rejected the mainstream parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — In France’s most consequential election in recent history, voters on Sunday chose Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen to go to a runoff to determine the next president, official returns showed. One is a political novice, the other a far-right firebrand — both outsiders, but with starkly different visions for the country.

articles.headline: AT&T’s Words on Time Warner Deal Say ‘Underdog.’ Its Actions Speak Otherwise.
articles.snippet: AT&T has told federal regulators it needs the merger to compete with cable companies. But it has acted like a powerhouse in dealings with cities and states.
articles.abstract: AT&T has told federal regulators it needs the merger to compete with cable companies. But it has acted like a powerhouse in dealings with cities and states.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Here in the nation’s capital, AT&T has painted itself as an underdog that needs to merge with Time Warner in a blockbuster $85 billion deal to compete with powerful cable companies.

articles.headline: How Google Cashes In on the Space Right Under the Search Bar
articles.snippet: The internet real estate, used for an expanding array of ad formats, is a prime driver of huge quarterly profits for the parent company, Alphabet.
articles.abstract: The internet real estate, used for an expanding array of ad formats, is a prime driver of huge quarterly profits for the parent company, Alphabet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Before Sergey Brin and Larry Page founded Google, they wrote a research paper as doctoral students at Stanford University in which they questioned the appropriateness of ads on search engines.

articles.headline: With Bill O’Reilly Out, Fox Rivals See a Chance to Move In
articles.snippet: For the first time in nearly two decades, Bill O’Reilly will not be kicking off Fox News’s prime-time lineup. The other cable networks have noticed.
articles.abstract: For the first time in nearly two decades, Bill O’Reilly will not be kicking off Fox News’s prime-time lineup. The other cable networks have noticed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting this week, a new era for prime-time cable news begins.

articles.headline: Trump Saved Carrier Jobs. These Workers Weren’t as Lucky.
articles.snippet: At an Indiana factory operated by the same corporate parent, more than 700 blue-collar workers are being laid off as their jobs are moved to Mexico.
articles.abstract: At an Indiana factory operated by the same corporate parent, more than 700 blue-collar workers are being laid off as their jobs are moved to Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, Ind. — These are the Indiana workers whose jobs President Trump didn’t save.

articles.headline: Floyd Abrams Sees Trump’s Anti-Media Tweets as Double-Edged Swords
articles.snippet: Mr. Abrams, a titan of free speech jurisprudence, says the Twitter trail could be a gift to lawyers defending journalists during leak investigations.
articles.abstract: Mr. Abrams, a titan of free speech jurisprudence, says the Twitter trail could be a gift to lawyers defending journalists during leak investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Monday, the sun rose in the east, the black-capped chickadee sang its spring mating song and President Trump attacked American journalists in a tweet. This latest one read: “The Fake Media (not Real Media) has gotten even worse since the election. Every story is badly slanted. We have to hold them to the truth!”

articles.headline: ‘This Is Deadly Serious’: French Parties Set Sights on Marine Le Pen
articles.snippet: Ms. Le Pen’s advancement to France’s presidential runoff on May 7 is a political earthquake. But now other parties are unifying to stop her.
articles.abstract: Ms. Le Pen’s advancement to France’s presidential runoff on May 7 is a political earthquake. But now other parties are unifying to stop her.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Not since World War II has the anti-immigrant far right been closer to gaining power in France. With her second-place finish on Sunday in the first round of the presidential election, Marine Le Pen has dragged her National Front party from the dark fringes of its first 40 years.

articles.headline: French Markets Surge as Euro Withstands Attack From the Right
articles.snippet: With the prospect that Marine Le Pen could claim the presidency sowing concerns about the currency, the results of the election’s first round provided some respite.
articles.abstract: With the prospect that Marine Le Pen could claim the presidency sowing concerns about the currency, the results of the election’s first round provided some respite.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The euro has avoided another existential crisis that might have wreaked havoc on Europe and the global economy. That was the conclusion investors divined from the first round of voting in the French presidential election, prompting exuberant buying on markets around the world on Monday.

articles.headline: No Longer a Dream: Silicon Valley Takes On the Flying Car
articles.snippet: This isn’t science fiction. A number of start-ups as well as big aerospace firms are trying to build personal aircraft you could fly around town.
articles.abstract: This isn’t science fiction. A number of start-ups as well as big aerospace firms are trying to build personal aircraft you could fly around town.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEARLAKE, Calif. — On a recent afternoon, an aerospace engineer working for a small Silicon Valley company called Kitty Hawk piloted a flying car above a scenic lake about 100 miles north of San Francisco.

articles.headline: With Ally in Oval Office, Immigration Hard-Liners Ascend to Power
articles.snippet: Proponents of a tough stance on illegal entry have taken top jobs in the Trump administration, and they are seeing their ideas become policy.
articles.abstract: Proponents of a tough stance on illegal entry have taken top jobs in the Trump administration, and they are seeing their ideas become policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: After sending more than 13,000 Twitter messages in less than three years, Jon Feere, an outspoken opponent of illegal immigration, suddenly went silent after Inauguration Day.
